098/**
099 * Class illustrating use of {@link SQLXML} to operate on XML data.
100 *<p>
101 * This class also serves as the mapping class for a composite type
102 * {@code javatest.onexml}, the better to verify that {@link SQLData}
103 * input/output works too. That's why it has to implement SQLData.
104 *<p>
105 * Everything mentioning the type XML here needs a conditional implementor tag
106 * in case of being loaded into a PostgreSQL instance built without that type.
107 */
108@SQLActions({
109    @SQLAction(provides="postgresql_xml", install=
110        "SELECT CASE (SELECT 1 FROM pg_type WHERE typname = 'xml') WHEN 1" +
111        " THEN set_config('pljava.implementors', 'postgresql_xml,' || " +
112        " current_setting('pljava.implementors'), true) " +
113        "END"
114    ),
115
116    @SQLAction(implementor="postgresql_ge_80400",
117        provides="postgresql_xml_ge84",
118        install=
119        "SELECT CASE (SELECT 1 FROM pg_type WHERE typname = 'xml') WHEN 1" +
120        " THEN set_config('pljava.implementors', 'postgresql_xml_ge84,' || " +
121        " current_setting('pljava.implementors'), true) " +
122        "END"
123    ),
124
125    @SQLAction(implementor="postgresql_xml_ge84", requires="echoXMLParameter",
126        install=
127        "WITH" +
128        " s(how) AS (SELECT generate_series(1, 7))," +
129        " t(x) AS (" +
130        "  SELECT table_to_xml('pg_catalog.pg_operator', true, false, '')" +
131        " )," +
132        " r(howin, howout, isdoc) AS (" +
133        "  SELECT" +
134        "   i.how, o.how," +
135        "   javatest.echoxmlparameter(x, i.how, o.how) IS DOCUMENT" +
136        "  FROM" +
137        "   t, s AS i, s AS o" +
138        "  WHERE" +
139        "   NOT (i.how = 6 and o.how = 7)" + // 6->7 unreliable in some JREs
140        " ) " +
141        "SELECT" +
142        " CASE WHEN every(isdoc)" +
143        "  THEN javatest.logmessage('INFO', 'SQLXML echos succeeded')" +
144        "  ELSE javatest.logmessage('WARNING', 'SQLXML echos had problems')" +
145        " END " +
146        "FROM" +
147        " r"
148    ),
149
150    @SQLAction(implementor="postgresql_xml_ge84", requires="proxiedXMLEcho",
151        install=
152        "WITH" +
153        " s(how) AS (SELECT unnest('{1,2,4,5,6,7}'::int[]))," +
154        " t(x) AS (" +
155        "  SELECT table_to_xml('pg_catalog.pg_operator', true, false, '')" +
156        " )," +
157        " r(how, isdoc) AS (" +
158        "  SELECT" +
159        "   how," +
160        "   javatest.proxiedxmlecho(x, how) IS DOCUMENT" +
161        "  FROM" +
162        "   t, s" +
163        " )" +
164        "SELECT" +
165        " CASE WHEN every(isdoc)" +
166        "  THEN javatest.logmessage('INFO', 'proxied SQLXML echos succeeded')" +
167        "  ELSE javatest.logmessage('WARNING'," +
168        "       'proxied SQLXML echos had problems')" +
169        " END " +
170        "FROM" +
171        " r"
172    ),
173
174    @SQLAction(implementor="postgresql_xml_ge84", requires="lowLevelXMLEcho",
175        install={
176        "SELECT" +
177        " preparexmlschema('schematest', $$" +
178        "<xs:schema" +
179        " xmlns:xs='http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema'" +
180        " targetNamespace='urn:testme'" +
181        " elementFormDefault='qualified'>" +
182        " <xs:element name='row'>" +
183        "  <xs:complexType>" +
184        "   <xs:sequence>" +
185        "    <xs:element name='textcol' type='xs:string' nillable='true'/>" +
186        "    <xs:element name='intcol' type='xs:integer' nillable='true'/>" +
187        "   </xs:sequence>" +
188        "  </xs:complexType>" +
189        " </xs:element>" +
190        "</xs:schema>" +
191        "$$, 'http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema', 5)",
192
193        "WITH" +
194        " s(how) AS (SELECT unnest('{4,5,7}'::int[]))," +
195        " r(isdoc) AS (" +
196        " SELECT" +
197        "  javatest.lowlevelxmlecho(" +
198        "   query_to_xml(" +
199        "    'SELECT ''hi'' AS textcol, 1 AS intcol', true, true, 'urn:testme'"+
200        "   ), how, params) IS DOCUMENT" +
201        " FROM" +
202        "  s," +
203        "  (SELECT 'schematest' AS schema) AS params" +
204        " )" +
205        "SELECT" +
206        " CASE WHEN every(isdoc)" +
207        "  THEN javatest.logmessage('INFO', 'XML Schema tests succeeded')" +
208        "  ELSE javatest.logmessage('WARNING'," +
209        "       'XML Schema tests had problems')" +
210        " END " +
211        "FROM" +
212        " r"
213        }
214    ),
215
216    @SQLAction(implementor="postgresql_xml",
217               requires={"prepareXMLTransform", "transformXML"},
218        install={
219            "SELECT" +
220            " javatest.prepareXMLTransform('distinctElementNames'," +
221            "'<xsl:transform version=''1.0''" +
222            " xmlns:xsl=''http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform''" +
223            " xmlns:exsl=''http://exslt.org/common''" +
224            " xmlns:set=''http://exslt.org/sets''" +
225            " extension-element-prefixes=''exsl set''" +
226            ">" +
227            " <xsl:output method=''xml'' indent=''no''/>" +
228            " <xsl:template match=''/''>" +
229            "  <xsl:variable name=''enames''>" +
230            "   <xsl:for-each select=''//*''>" +
231            "    <ename><xsl:value-of select=''local-name()''/></ename>" +
232            "   </xsl:for-each>" +
233            "  </xsl:variable>" +
234            "  <xsl:for-each" +
235            "   select=''set:distinct(exsl:node-set($enames)/ename)''>" +
236            "   <xsl:sort select=''string()''/>" +
237            "   <den><xsl:value-of select=''.''/></den>" +
238            "  </xsl:for-each>" +
239            " </xsl:template>" +
240            "</xsl:transform>', 5, true)",
241
242            "SELECT" +
243            " CASE WHEN" +
244            "  javatest.transformXML('distinctElementNames'," +
245            "   '<a><c/><e/><b/><b/><d/></a>', 5, 5)::text" +
246            "  =" +
247            "   '<den>a</den><den>b</den><den>c</den><den>d</den><den>e</den>'"+
248            "  THEN javatest.logmessage('INFO', 'XSLT 1.0 test succeeded')" +
249            "  ELSE javatest.logmessage('WARNING', 'XSLT 1.0 test failed')" +
250            " END"
251        }
252    )
253})
254@MappedUDT(schema="javatest", name="onexml", structure="c1 xml",
255           implementor="postgresql_xml",
256           comment="A composite type mapped by the PassXML example class")
257public class PassXML implements SQLData
258{
259    static SQLXML s_sx;
260
261    static TransformerFactory s_tf = TransformerFactory.newInstance();
262
263    static Map<String,Templates> s_tpls = new HashMap<>();
264
265    static Map<String,Schema> s_schemas = new HashMap<>();
266
267    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml")
268    public static String inXMLoutString(SQLXML in) throws SQLException
269    {
270        return in.getString();
271    }
272
273    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml")
274    public static SQLXML inStringoutXML(String in) throws SQLException
275    {
276        Connection c = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
277        SQLXML result = c.createSQLXML();
278        result.setString(in);
279        return result;
280    }
281
282    /**
283     * Echo an XML parameter back, exercising seven different ways
284     * (howin =&gt; 1-7) of reading an SQLXML object, and seven
285     * (howout =&gt; 1-7) of returning one.
286     *<p>
287     * If howin =&gt; 0, the XML parameter is simply saved in a static. It can
288     * be read in a subsequent call with sx =&gt; null, but only in the same
289     * transaction.
290     *<p>
291     * The "echoing" is done (in the {@code echoXML} method below) using a
292     * {@code Transformer}, that is, the "TrAX" Transformation API for XML
293     * supplied in Java. It illustrates how an identity {@code Transformer} can
294     * be used to get the XML content from the source to the result for any of
295     * the APIs selectable by howin and howout.
296     *<p>
297     * It also illustrates something else. When using StAX (6 for howin
298     * or howout) and XML of the {@code CONTENT} flavor (multiple top-level
299     * elements, characters outside the top element, etc.), it is easy to
300     * construct examples that fail. The fault is not really with the StAX API,
301     * nor with TrAX proper, but with the small handful of bridge classes that
302     * were added to the JRE with StAX's first appearance, to make it
303     * interoperate with TrAX. It is not that those classes completely overlook
304     * the {@code CONTENT} case: they make some efforts to handle it. Just not
305     * the right ones, and given the Java developers' usual reluctance to change
306     * such longstanding behavior, that's probably not getting fixed.
307     *<p>
308     * Moral: StAX is a nice API, have no fear to use it directly in
309     * freshly-developed code, but: when using TrAX, make every effort to supply
310     * a {@code Transformer} with {@code Source} and {@code Result} objects of
311     * <em>any</em> kind other than StAX.
312     */
313    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml",
314              provides="echoXMLParameter")
315    public static SQLXML echoXMLParameter(SQLXML sx, int howin, int howout)
316    throws SQLException
317    {
318        if ( null == sx )
319            sx = s_sx;
320        if ( 0 == howin )
321        {
322            s_sx = sx;
323            return null;
324        }
325        return echoSQLXML(sx, howin, howout);
326    }
327
328    /**
329     * Echo an XML parameter back, but with parameter and return types of
330     * PostgreSQL {@code text}.
331     *<p>
332     * The other version of this method needs a conditional implementor tag
333     * because it cannot be declared in a PostgreSQL instance that was built
334     * without {@code libxml} support and the PostgreSQL {@code XML} type.
335     * But this version can, simply by mapping the {@code SQLXML} parameter
336     * and return types to the SQL {@code text} type. The Java code is no
337     * different.
338     *<p>
339     * Note that it's possible for both declarations to coexist in PostgreSQL
340     * (because as far as it is concerned, their signatures are different), but
341     * these two Java methods cannot have the same name (because they differ
342     * only in annotations, not in the declared Java types). So, this one needs
343     * a slightly tweaked name, and a {@code name} attribute in the annotation
344     * so PostgreSQL sees the right name.
345     */
346    @Function(schema="javatest", name="echoXMLParameter", type="text")
347    public static SQLXML echoXMLParameter_(
348        @SQLType("text") SQLXML sx, int howin, int howout)
349    throws SQLException
350    {
351        return echoXMLParameter(sx, howin, howout);
352    }
353
354    /**
355     * "Echo" an XML parameter not by creating a new writable {@code SQLXML}
356     * object at all, but simply returning the passed-in readable one untouched.
357     */
358    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml")
359    public static SQLXML bounceXMLParameter(SQLXML sx) throws SQLException
360    {
361        return sx;
362    }
363
364    /**
365     * Just like {@link bounceXMLParameter} but with parameter and return typed
366     * as {@code text}, and so usable on a PostgreSQL instance lacking the XML
367     * type.
368     */
369    @Function(schema="javatest", type="text", name="bounceXMLParameter")
370    public static SQLXML bounceXMLParameter_(@SQLType("text") SQLXML sx)
371    throws SQLException
372    {
373        return sx;
374    }
375
376    /**
377     * Just like {@link bounceXMLParameter} but with the parameter typed as
378     * {@code text} and the return type left as XML, so functions as a cast.
379     *<p>
380     * Slower than the other cases, because it must verify that the input really
381     * is XML before blindly calling it a PostgreSQL XML type. But the speed
382     * compares respectably to PostgreSQL's own CAST(text AS xml), at least for
383     * larger values; I am seeing Java pull ahead right around 32kB of XML data
384     * and beat PG by a factor of 2 or better at sizes of 1 or 2 MB.
385     * Unsurprisingly, PG has the clear advantage when values are very short.
386     */
387    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml")
388    public static SQLXML castTextXML(@SQLType("text") SQLXML sx)
389    throws SQLException
390    {
391        return sx;
392    }
393
394    /**
395     * Precompile an XSL transform {@code source} and save it (for the
396     * current session) as {@code name}.
397     *<p>
398     * Each value of {@code how}, 1-7, selects a different way of presenting
399     * the {@code SQLXML} object to the XSL processor.
400     *<p>
401     * Passing {@code true} for {@code enableExtensionFunctions} allows the
402     * transform to use extensions that the Java XSLT implementation supports,
403     * such as functions from EXSLT. Those are disabled by default.
404     *<p>
405     * Out of the box, Java's transformers only support XSLT 1.0. See the S9
406     * example for more capabilities (at the cost of downloading the Saxon jar).
407     */
408    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml",
409              provides="prepareXMLTransform")
410    public static void prepareXMLTransform(String name, SQLXML source, int how,
411        @SQLType(defaultValue="false") boolean enableExtensionFunctions)
412    throws SQLException
413    {
414        TransformerFactory tf = TransformerFactory.newInstance();
415        String exf =
416          "http://www.oracle.com/xml/jaxp/properties/enableExtensionFunctions";
417        try
418        {
419            tf.setFeature(exf, enableExtensionFunctions);
420            s_tpls.put(name, tf.newTemplates(sxToSource(source, how)));
421        }
422        catch ( TransformerException te )
423        {
424            throw new SQLException("XML transformation failed", te);
425        }
426    }
427
428    /**
429     * Transform some XML according to a named transform prepared with
430     * {@code prepareXMLTransform}.
431     */
432    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml",
433              provides="transformXML")
434    public static SQLXML transformXML(
435        String transformName, SQLXML source, int howin, int howout)
436    throws SQLException
437    {
438        Templates tpl = s_tpls.get(transformName);
439        Source src = sxToSource(source, howin);
440        Connection c = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
441        SQLXML result = c.createSQLXML();
442        Result rlt = sxToResult(result, howout);
443
444        try
445        {
446            Transformer t = tpl.newTransformer();
447            t.transform(src, rlt);
448        }
449        catch ( TransformerException te )
450        {
451            throw new SQLException("XML transformation failed", te);
452        }
453
454        return ensureClosed(rlt, result, howout);
455    }
456
457    /**
458     * Precompile a schema {@code source} in schema language {@code lang}
459     * and save it (for the current session) as {@code name}.
460     *<p>
461     * Each value of {@code how}, 1-7, selects a different way of presenting
462     * the {@code SQLXML} object to the schema parser.
463     *<p>
464     * The {@code lang} parameter is a URI that identifies a known schema
465     * language. The only language a Java runtime is required to support is
466     * W3C XML Schema 1.0, with URI {@code http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema}.
467     */
468    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml")
469    public static void prepareXMLSchema(
470        String name, SQLXML source, String lang, int how)
471    throws SQLException
472    {
473        try
474        {
475            s_schemas.put(name,
476                SchemaFactory.newInstance(lang)
477                .newSchema(sxToSource(source, how)));
478        }
479        catch ( SAXException e )
480        {
481            throw new SQLException(
482                "failed to prepare schema: " + e.getMessage(), e);
483        }
484    }
485
486    private static SQLXML echoSQLXML(SQLXML sx, int howin, int howout)
487    throws SQLException
488    {
489        Connection c = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
490        SQLXML rx = c.createSQLXML();
491        Source src = sxToSource(sx, howin);
492        Result rlt = sxToResult(rx, howout);
493
494        try
495        {
496            Transformer t = s_tf.newTransformer();
497            /*
498             * For the non-SAX/StAX/DOM flavors of output, you're responsible
499             * for setting the Transformer to use the server encoding.
500             */
501            if ( howout < 5 )
502                t.setOutputProperty(ENCODING,
503                    System.getProperty("org.postgresql.server.encoding"));
504            t.transform(src, rlt);
505        }
506        catch ( TransformerException te )
507        {
508            throw new SQLException("XML transformation failed", te);
509        }
510
511        return ensureClosed(rlt, rx, howout);
512    }
513
514    /**
515     * Echo the XML parameter back, using lower-level manipulations than
516     * {@code echoXMLParameter}.
517     *<p>
518     * This illustrates how the simple use of {@code t.transform(src,rlt)}
519     * in {@code echoSQLXML} substitutes for a lot of fiddly case-by-case code,
520     * but when coding for a specific case, all the generality of {@code
521     * transform} may not be needed. It can be interesting to compare memory use
522     * when XML values are large.
523     *<p>
524     * This method has been revised to demonstrate, even for low-level
525     * manipulations, how much fiddliness can now be avoided through use of the
526     * {@link Adjusting.XML.SourceResult} class, and how to make adjustments to
527     * parsing restrictions by passing the optional row-typed parameter
528     * <em>adjust</em>, which defaults to an empty row. For example, passing
529     *<pre>
530     * adjust =&gt; (select a from
531     *            (true as allowdtd, true as expandentityreferences) as a)
532     *</pre>
533     * would allow a document that contains an internal DTD subset and uses
534     * entities defined there.
535     *<p>
536     * The older, pre-{@code SourceResult} code for doing low-level XML echo
537     * has been moved to the {@code oldSchoolLowLevelEcho} method below. It can
538     * still be exercised by calling this method, explicitly passing
539     * {@code adjust => NULL}.
540     */
541    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml_ge84",
542        provides="lowLevelXMLEcho")
543    public static SQLXML lowLevelXMLEcho(
544        SQLXML sx, int how, @SQLType(defaultValue={}) ResultSet adjust)
545    throws SQLException
546    {
547        Connection c = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
548        SQLXML rx = c.createSQLXML();
549
550        if ( null == adjust )
551            return oldSchoolLowLevelEcho(rx, sx, how);
552
553        Adjusting.XML.SourceResult axsr =
554            rx.setResult(Adjusting.XML.SourceResult.class);
555
556        switch ( how )
557        {
558        /*
559         * The first four cases all present the content as unparsed bytes or
560         * characters, so there is nothing to adjust on the source side.
561         */
562        case 1:
563            axsr.set(new StreamSource(sx.getBinaryStream()));
564            break;
565        case 2:
566            axsr.set(new StreamSource(sx.getCharacterStream()));
567            break;
568        case 3:
569            axsr.set(sx.getString());
570            break;
571        case 4:
572            axsr.set(sx.getSource(StreamSource.class));
573            break;
574        /*
575         * The remaining cases present the content in parsed form, and therefore
576         * may involve parsers that can be adjusted according to the supplied
577         * preferences.
578         */
579        case 5:
580            axsr.set(applyAdjustments(adjust,
581                sx.getSource(Adjusting.XML.SAXSource.class)));
582            break;
583        case 6:
584            axsr.set(applyAdjustments(adjust,
585                sx.getSource(Adjusting.XML.StAXSource.class)));
586            break;
587        case 7:
588            axsr.set(applyAdjustments(adjust,
589                sx.getSource(Adjusting.XML.DOMSource.class)));
590            break;
591        default:
592            throw new SQLDataException(
593                "how must be 1-7 for lowLevelXMLEcho", "22003");
594        }
595
596        /*
597         * Adjustments can also be applied to the SourceResult itself, where
598         * they will affect any implicitly-created parser used to verify or
599         * re-encode the content, if it was supplied in unparsed form.
600         */
601        return applyAdjustments(adjust, axsr).get().getSQLXML();
602    }
603
604    /**
605     * Apply adjustments (supplied as a row type with a named column for each
606     * desired adjustment and its value) to an instance of
607     * {@link Adjusting.XML.Parsing}.
608     *<p>
609     * Column names in the <em>adjust</em> row are case-insensitive versions of
610     * the method names in {@link Adjusting.XML.Parsing}, and the value of each
611     * column should be of the appropriate type (at present, boolean for all of
612     * them).
613     * @param adjust A row type as described above, possibly of no columns if no
614     * adjustments are wanted
615     * @param axp An instance of Adjusting.XML.Parsing
616     * @return axp, after applying any adjustments
617     */
618    public static <T extends Adjusting.XML.Parsing<? super T>>
619    T applyAdjustments(ResultSet adjust, T axp)
620    throws SQLException
621    {
622        ResultSetMetaData rsmd = adjust.getMetaData();
623        int n = rsmd.getColumnCount();
624
625        for ( int i = 1; i <= n; ++i )
626        {
627            String k = rsmd.getColumnLabel(i);
628            if ( "allowDTD".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
629                axp.allowDTD(adjust.getBoolean(i));
630            else if ( "externalGeneralEntities".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
631                axp.externalGeneralEntities(adjust.getBoolean(i));
632            else if ( "externalParameterEntities".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
633                axp.externalParameterEntities(adjust.getBoolean(i));
634            else if ( "loadExternalDTD".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
635                axp.loadExternalDTD(adjust.getBoolean(i));
636            else if ( "xIncludeAware".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
637                axp.xIncludeAware(adjust.getBoolean(i));
638            else if ( "expandEntityReferences".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
639                axp.expandEntityReferences(adjust.getBoolean(i));
640            else if ( "elementAttributeLimit".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
641                axp.elementAttributeLimit(adjust.getInt(i));
642            else if ( "entityExpansionLimit".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
643                axp.entityExpansionLimit(adjust.getInt(i));
644            else if ( "entityReplacementLimit".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
645                axp.entityReplacementLimit(adjust.getInt(i));
646            else if ( "maxElementDepth".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
647                axp.maxElementDepth(adjust.getInt(i));
648            else if ( "maxGeneralEntitySizeLimit".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
649                axp.maxGeneralEntitySizeLimit(adjust.getInt(i));
650            else if ( "maxParameterEntitySizeLimit".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
651                axp.maxParameterEntitySizeLimit(adjust.getInt(i));
652            else if ( "maxXMLNameLimit".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
653                axp.maxXMLNameLimit(adjust.getInt(i));
654            else if ( "totalEntitySizeLimit".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
655                axp.totalEntitySizeLimit(adjust.getInt(i));
656            else if ( "accessExternalDTD".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
657                axp.accessExternalDTD(adjust.getString(i));
658            else if ( "accessExternalSchema".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
659                axp.accessExternalSchema(adjust.getString(i));
660            else if ( "schema".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
661            {
662                try
663                {
664                    axp.schema(s_schemas.get(adjust.getString(i)));
665                }
666                catch (UnsupportedOperationException e)
667                {
668                }
669            }
670            else
671                throw new SQLDataException(
672                    "unrecognized name \"" + k + "\" for parser adjustment",
673                    "22000");
674        }
675        return axp;
676    }
677
678    /**
679     * An obsolescent example, showing what was required to copy from one
680     * {@code SQLXML} object to another, using the various supported APIs,
681     * without using {@link Adjusting.XML.SourceResult}, or at least without
682     * using it much. It is still used in case 4 to be sure of getting a
683     * {@code StreamResult} that matches the byte-or-character-ness of the
684     * {@code StreamSource}. How to handle that case without
685     * {@code SourceResult} is left as an exercise.
686     */
687    private static SQLXML oldSchoolLowLevelEcho(SQLXML rx, SQLXML sx, int how)
688    throws SQLException
689    {
690        try
691        {
692            switch ( how )
693            {
694            case 1:
695                InputStream is = sx.getBinaryStream();
696                OutputStream os = rx.setBinaryStream();
697                shovelBytes(is, os);
698                break;
699            case 2:
700                Reader r = sx.getCharacterStream();
701                Writer w = rx.setCharacterStream();
702                shovelChars(r, w);
703                break;
704            case 3:
705                rx.setString(sx.getString());
706                break;
707            case 4:
708                StreamSource ss = sx.getSource(StreamSource.class);
709                Adjusting.XML.StreamResult sr =
710                    rx.setResult(Adjusting.XML.StreamResult.class);
711                is = ss.getInputStream();
712                r  = ss.getReader();
713                if ( null != is )
714                {
715                    os = sr.preferBinaryStream().get().getOutputStream();
716                    shovelBytes(is, os);
717                    break;
718                }
719                if ( null != r )
720                {
721                    w  = sr.preferCharacterStream().get().getWriter();
722                    shovelChars(r, w);
723                    break;
724                }
725                throw new SQLDataException(
726                    "StreamSource contained neither InputStream nor Reader");
727            case 5:
728                SAXSource sxs = sx.getSource(SAXSource.class);
729                SAXResult sxr = rx.setResult(SAXResult.class);
730                XMLReader xr  = sxs.getXMLReader();
731                if ( null == xr )
732                {
733                    SAXParserFactory spf = SAXParserFactory.newInstance();
734                    spf.setNamespaceAware(true);
735                    xr = spf.newSAXParser().getXMLReader();
736                    /*
737                     * Important: before copying this example code for another
738                     * use, consider whether the input XML might be untrusted.
739                     * If so, the new XMLReader created here should have several
740                     * features given safe default settings as outlined in the
741                     * OWASP guidelines. (This branch is not reached when sx is
742                     * a PL/Java native SQLXML instance, as xr will be non-null
743                     * and already configured.)
744                     */
745                }
746                ContentHandler ch = sxr.getHandler();
747                xr.setContentHandler(ch);
748                if ( ch instanceof DTDHandler )
749                    xr.setDTDHandler((DTDHandler)ch);
750                LexicalHandler lh = sxr.getLexicalHandler();
751                if ( null == lh  &&  ch instanceof LexicalHandler )
752                lh = (LexicalHandler)ch;
753                if ( null != lh )
754                    xr.setProperty(
755                        "http://xml.org/sax/properties/lexical-handler", lh);
756                xr.parse(sxs.getInputSource());
757                break;
758            case 6:
759                StAXSource sts = sx.getSource(StAXSource.class);
760                StAXResult str = rx.setResult(StAXResult.class);
761                XMLOutputFactory xof = XMLOutputFactory.newInstance();
762                /*
763                 * The Source has either an event reader or a stream reader. Use
764                 * the event reader directly, or create one around the stream
765                 * reader.
766                 */
767                XMLEventReader xer = sts.getXMLEventReader();
768                if ( null == xer )
769                {
770                    XMLInputFactory  xif = XMLInputFactory .newInstance();
771                    xif.setProperty(xif.IS_NAMESPACE_AWARE, true);
772                    /*
773                     * Important: before copying this example code for another
774                     * use, consider whether the input XML might be untrusted.
775                     * If so, the new XMLInputFactory created here might want
776                     * several properties given safe default settings as
777                     * outlined in the OWASP guidelines. (When sx is a PL/Java
778                     * native SQLXML instance, the XMLStreamReader obtained
779                     * below will already have been so configured.)
780                     */
781                    xer = xif.createXMLEventReader(sts.getXMLStreamReader());
782                }
783                /*
784                 * Were you thinking the above could be simply
785                 * createXMLEventReader(sts) by analogy with the writer below?
786                 * Good thought, but the XMLInputFactory implementation that's
787                 * included in OpenJDK doesn't implement the case where the
788                 * Source argument is a StAXSource! Two lines would do it.
789                 */
790                /*
791                 * Because of a regression in Java 9 and later, the line below,
792                 * while working in Java 8 and earlier, will produce a
793                 * ClassCastException in Java 9 through (for sure) 12, (almost
794                 * certainly) 13, and on until some future version fixes the
795                 * regression, if ever, if 'str' wraps any XMLStreamWriter
796                 * implementation other than the inaccessible one from the guts
797                 * of the JDK itself. The bug has been reported but (as of this
798                 * writing) is still in the maddening limbo phase of the Java
799                 * bug reporting cycle, where no bug number can refer to it. See
800                 * lowLevelXMLEcho() above for code to do this copy successfully
801                 * using an Adjusting.XML.SourceResult.
802                 */
803                XMLEventWriter xew = xof.createXMLEventWriter(str);
804                xew.add(xer);
805                xew.close();
806                xer.close();
807                break;
808            case 7:
809                DOMSource ds = sx.getSource(DOMSource.class);
810                DOMResult dr = rx.setResult(DOMResult.class);
811                dr.setNode(ds.getNode());
812                break;
813            default:
814                throw new SQLDataException(
815                    "how must be 1-7 for lowLevelXMLEcho", "22003");
816            }
817        }
818        catch ( IOException e )
819        {
820            throw new SQLException(
821                "IOException in lowLevelXMLEcho", "58030", e);
822        }
823        catch (
824            ParserConfigurationException | SAXException | XMLStreamException e )
825        {
826            throw new SQLException(
827                "XML exception in lowLevelXMLEcho", "22000", e);
828        }
829        return rx;
830    }
831
832    /**
833     * Proxy a PL/Java SQLXML source object as if it were of a non-PL/Java
834     * implementing class, to confirm that it can still be returned successfully
835     * to PostgreSQL.
836     * @param sx readable {@code SQLXML} object to proxy
837     * @param how 1,2,4,5,6,7 determines what subclass of {@code Source} will be
838     * returned by {@code getSource}.
839     */
840    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml",
841              provides="proxiedXMLEcho")
842    public static SQLXML proxiedXMLEcho(SQLXML sx, int how)
843    throws SQLException
844    {
845        return new SQLXMLProxy(sx, how);
846    }

848    /**
849     * Supply a sequence of bytes to be the exact (encoded) content of an XML
850     * value, which will be returned; if the encoding is not UTF-8, the value
851     * should begin with an XML Decl that names the encoding.
852     *<p>
853     * Constructs an {@code SQLXML} instance that will return the supplied
854     * content as a {@code StreamSource} wrapping an {@code InputStream}, or via
855     * {@code getBinaryStream}, but fail if asked for any other form.
856     */
857    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml",
858              provides="mockedXMLEchoB")
859    public static SQLXML mockedXMLEcho(byte[] bytes)
860    throws SQLException
861    {
862        return new SQLXMLMock(bytes);
863    }

865    /**
866     * Supply a sequence of characters to be the exact (Unicode) content of an
867     * XML value, which will be returned; if the value begins with an XML Decl
868     * that names an encoding, the content will be assumed to contain only
869     * characters representable in that encoding.
870     *<p>
871     * Constructs an {@code SQLXML} instance that will return the supplied
872     * content as a {@code StreamSource} wrapping a {@code Reader}, or via
873     * {@code getCharacterStream}, but fail if asked for any other form.
874     */
875    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml",
876              provides="mockedXMLEchoC")
877    public static SQLXML mockedXMLEcho(String chars)
878    throws SQLException
879    {
880        return new SQLXMLMock(chars);
881    }

883    /**
884     * Text-typed variant of lowLevelXMLEcho (does not require XML type).
885     *<p>
886     * It does declare a parameter default, limiting it to PostgreSQL 8.4 or
887     * later.
888     */
889    @Function(schema="javatest", name="lowLevelXMLEcho",
890        type="text", implementor="postgresql_ge_80400")
891    public static SQLXML lowLevelXMLEcho_(@SQLType("text") SQLXML sx, int how,
892        @SQLType(defaultValue={}) ResultSet adjust)
893    throws SQLException
894    {
895        return lowLevelXMLEcho(sx, how, adjust);

898    /**
899     * Low-level XML echo where the Java parameter and return type are String.
900     */
901    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml", type="xml")
902    public static String lowLevelXMLEcho(@SQLType("xml") String x)
903    throws SQLException
904    {
905        return x;
906    }
907
908    /**
909     * Create some XML, pass it to a {@code SELECT ?} prepared statement,
910     * retrieve it from the result set, and return it via the out-parameter
911     * result set of this {@code RECORD}-returning function.
912     */
913    @Function(schema="javatest", type="RECORD")
914    public static boolean xmlInStmtAndRS(ResultSet out) throws SQLException
915    {
916        Connection c = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
917        SQLXML x = c.createSQLXML();
918        x.setString("<a/>");
919        PreparedStatement ps = c.prepareStatement("SELECT ?");
920        ps.setObject(1, x, Types.SQLXML);
921        ResultSet rs = ps.executeQuery();
922        rs.next();
923        if ( Types.SQLXML != rs.getMetaData().getColumnType(1) )
924            logMessage("WARNING",
925                "ResultSetMetaData.getColumnType() misreports SQLXML");
926        x = rs.getSQLXML(1);
927        ps.close();
928        out.updateObject(1, x);
929        return true;
930    }
931
932    /**
933     * Test serialization into the PostgreSQL server encoding by returning
934     * a text node, optionally wrapped in an element, containing the supplied
935     * stuff.
936     *<p>
937     * The stuff is supplied as a {@code bytea} and a named <em>encoding</em>,
938     * so it is easy to supply stuff that isn't in the server encoding and see
939     * what the serializer does with it.
940     *<p>
941     * As of this writing, if the <em>stuff</em>, decoded according to
942     * <em>encoding</em>, contains characters that are not representable in the
943     * server encoding, the serializers supplied in the JRE will:
944     *<ul>
945     *<li>SAX, DOM: replace the character with a numeric character reference if
946     * the node is wrapped in an element, but not outside of an element; there,
947     * PL/Java ensures an {@code UnmappableCharacterException} is thrown, as the
948     * serializer would otherwise silently lose information by replacing the
949     * character with a {@code ?}.
950     *<li>StAX: replace the character with a numeric character reference whether
951     * wrapped in an element or not (outside of an element, this officially
952     * violates the letter of the XML spec, but does not lose information, and
953     * is closer to the spirit of SQL/XML with its {@code XML(CONTENT)} type).
954     *</ul>
955     * @param stuff Content to be used in the text node
956     * @param encoding Name of an encoding; stuff will be decoded to Unicode
957     * according to this encoding, and then serialized into the server encoding,
958     * where possible.
959     * @param how Integer specifying which XML API to test, like every other how
960     * in this class; here the only valid choices are 5 (SAX), 6 (StAX), or
961     * 7 (DOM).
962     * @param inElement True if the text node should be wrapped in an element.
963     * @return The resulting XML content.
964     */
965    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml")
966    public static SQLXML xmlTextNode(
967        byte[] stuff, String encoding, int how, boolean inElement)
968        throws Exception
969    {
970        if ( 5 > how || how > 7 )
971            throw new SQLDataException(
972                "how must be 5-7 for xmlTextNode", "22003");
973
974        String stuffString = new String(stuff, encoding);
975        Connection c = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
976        SQLXML rx = c.createSQLXML();
977
978        switch ( how )
979        {
980        case 5:
981            SAXResult sxr = rx.setResult(SAXResult.class);
982            sxr.getHandler().startDocument();
983            if ( inElement )
984                sxr.getHandler().startElement("", "sax", "sax",
985                    new AttributesImpl());
986            sxr.getHandler().characters(
987                stuffString.toCharArray(), 0, stuffString.length());
988            if ( inElement )
989                sxr.getHandler().endElement("", "sax", "sax");
990            sxr.getHandler().endDocument();
991            break;
992        case 6:
993            StAXResult stxr = rx.setResult(StAXResult.class);
994            stxr.getXMLStreamWriter().writeStartDocument();
995            if ( inElement )
996                stxr.getXMLStreamWriter().writeStartElement("", "stax", "");
997            stxr.getXMLStreamWriter().writeCharacters(stuffString);
998            if ( inElement )
999                stxr.getXMLStreamWriter().writeEndElement();
1000            stxr.getXMLStreamWriter().writeEndDocument();
1001            break;
1002        case 7:
1003            DOMResult dr = rx.setResult(DOMResult.class);
1004            /*
1005             * Why request features XML and Traversal?
1006             * If the only features requested are from the set
1007             * {Core, XML, LS} and maybe XPath, you get a brain-damaged
1008             * DOMImplementation that violates the org.w3c.dom.DOMImplementation
1009             * contract, as createDocument still tries to make a document
1010             * element even when passed null,null,null when, according to the
1011             * contract, it should not. To get the real implementation that
1012             * works, ask for some feature it supports outside of that core set.
1013             * I don't really need Traversal, but by asking for it, I get what
1014             * I do need.
1015             */
1016            Document d = DOMImplementationRegistry.newInstance()
1017                .getDOMImplementation("XML Traversal")
1018                .createDocument(null, null, null);
1019            DocumentFragment df = d.createDocumentFragment();
1020            ( inElement ? df.appendChild(d.createElement("dom")) : df )
1021                .appendChild(d.createTextNode(stuffString));
1022            dr.setNode(df);
1023            break;
1024        }
1025        return rx;
1026    }
1027
1028    /**
1029     * Create and leave some number of SQLXML objects unclosed, unused, and
1030     * unreferenced, as a test of reclamation.
1031     * @param howmany Number of SQLXML instances to create.
1032     * @param how If nonzero, the flavor of writing to request on the object
1033     * before abandoning it; if zero, it is left in its initial, writable state.
1034     */
1035    @Function(schema="javatest")
1036    public static void unclosedSQLXML(int howmany, int how) throws SQLException
1037    {
1038        Connection c = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
1039        while ( howmany --> 0 )
1040        {
1041            SQLXML sx = c.createSQLXML();
1042            if ( 0 < how )
1043                sxToResult(sx, how);
1044        }
1045    }
1046
1047    private static Source sxToSource(SQLXML sx, int how) throws SQLException
1048    {
1049        switch ( how )
1050        {
1051            case  1: return new StreamSource(sx.getBinaryStream());
1052            case  2: return new StreamSource(sx.getCharacterStream());
1053            case  3: return new StreamSource(new StringReader(sx.getString()));
1054            case  4: return     sx.getSource(StreamSource.class);
1055            case  5: return     sx.getSource(SAXSource.class);
1056            case  6: return     sx.getSource(StAXSource.class);
1057            case  7: return     sx.getSource(DOMSource.class);
1058            default: throw new SQLDataException("how should be 1-7", "22003");
1059        }
1060    }
1061
1062    /**
1063     * Return some instance of {@code Result} for writing an {@code SQLXML}
1064     * object, depending on the parameter {@code how}.
1065     *<p>
1066     * Note that this method always returns a {@code Result}, even for cases
1067     * 1 and 2 (obtaining writable streams directly from the {@code SQLXML}
1068     * object; this method wraps them in {@code Result}), and case 3
1069     * ({@code setString}; this method creates a {@code StringWriter} and
1070     * returns it wrapped in a {@code Result}.
1071     *<p>
1072     * In case 3, it will be necessary, after writing, to get the {@code String}
1073     * from the {@code StringWriter}, and call {@code setString} with it.
1074     */
1075    private static Result sxToResult(SQLXML sx, int how) throws SQLException
1076    {
1077        switch ( how )
1078        {
1079            case  1: return new StreamResult(sx.setBinaryStream());
1080            case  2: return new StreamResult(sx.setCharacterStream());
1081            case  3: return new StreamResult(new StringWriter());
1082            case  4: return     sx.setResult(StreamResult.class);
1083            case  5: return     sx.setResult(SAXResult.class);
1084            case  6: return     sx.setResult(StAXResult.class);
1085            case  7:
1086                DOMResult r = sx.setResult(DOMResult.class);
1087                allowFragment(r); // else it'll accept only DOCUMENT form
1088                return r;
1089            default: throw new SQLDataException("how should be 1-7", "22003");
1090        }
1091    }
1092
1093    /**
1094     * Ensure the closing of whatever method was used to add content to
1095     * an {@code SQLXML} object.
1096     *<p>
1097     * Before a {@code SQLXML} object that has been written to can be used by
1098     * PostgreSQL (returned as a function result, plugged in as a prepared
1099     * statement parameter or into a {@code ResultSet}, etc.), the method used
1100     * for writing it must be "closed" to ensure the writing is complete.
1101     *<p>
1102     * If it is set with {@link SQLXML#setString setString}, nothing more is
1103     * needed; {@code setString} obviously sets the whole value at once. Any
1104     * {@code OutputStream} or {@code Writer} obtained from
1105     * {@link SQLXML#setBinaryStream setBinaryStream} or
1106     * {@link SQLXML#setCharacterStream setCharacterStream}, or from
1107     * {@link SQLXML#setResult setResult}{@code (StreamResult.class)}, has to be
1108     * explicitly closed (a {@link Transformer} does not close its
1109     * {@link Result} when the transformation is complete!).
1110     * Those are cases 1, 2, and 4 here.
1111     *<p>
1112     * Cases 5 ({@code SAXResult}) and 6 ({@code StAXResult}) need no special
1113     * attention; though the {@code Transformer} does not close them, the ones
1114     * returned by this {@code SQLXML} implementation are set up to close
1115     * themselves when the {@code endDocument} event is written.
1116     *<p>
1117     * Case 3 (test of {@code setString} is handled specially here. As this
1118     * class allows testing of all techniques for writing the {@code SQLXML}
1119     * object, and most of those involve a {@code Result}, case 3 is handled
1120     * by also constructing a {@code Result} over a {@link StringWriter} and
1121     * having the content written into that; this method then extracts the
1122     * content from the {@code StringWriter} and passes it to {@code setString}.
1123     * For cases 1 and 2, likewise, the stream obtained with
1124     * {@code getBinaryStream} or {@code getCharacterStream} has been wrapped in
1125     * a {@code Result} for generality in this example.
1126     *<p>
1127     * A typical application will not need the generality seen here; it
1128     * will usually know which technique it is using to write the {@code SQLXML}
1129     * object, and only needs to know how to close that if it needs closing.
1130     * @param r The {@code Result} onto which writing was done.
1131     * @param sx The {@code SQLXML} object being written.
1132     * @param how The integer used in this example class to select which method
1133     * of writing the {@code SQLXML} object was to be tested.
1134     * @return The {@code SQLXML} object {@code sx}, because why not?
1135     */
1136    public static SQLXML ensureClosed(Result r, SQLXML sx, int how)
1137    throws SQLException
1138    {
1139        switch ( how )
1140        {
1141        case 1:
1142        case 2:
1143        case 4:
1144            StreamResult sr = (StreamResult)r;
1145            OutputStream os = sr.getOutputStream();
1146            Writer w = sr.getWriter();
1147            try
1148            {
1149                if ( null != os )
1150                    os.close();
1151                if ( null != w )
1152                    w.close();
1153            }
1154            catch ( IOException ioe )
1155            {
1156                throw new SQLException(
1157                    "Failure closing SQLXML result", "XX000");
1158            }
1159            break;
1160        case 3:
1161            StringWriter sw = (StringWriter)((StreamResult)r).getWriter();
1162            String s = sw.toString();
1163            sx.setString(s);
1164            break;
1165        }
1166        return sx;
1167    }
1168
1169    /**
1170     * Configure a {@code DOMResult} to accept {@code CONTENT} (a/k/a
1171     * document fragment), not only the more restrictive {@code DOCUMENT}.
1172     *<p>
1173     * The other forms of {@code Result} that can be requested will happily
1174     * accept {@code XML(CONTENT)} and not just {@code XML(DOCUMENT)}.
1175     * The {@code DOMResult} is pickier, however: if you first call
1176     * {@link DOMResult#setNode setNode} with a {@code DocumentFragment}, it
1177     * will accept either form, but if you leave the node unset when passing the
1178     * {@code DOMResult} to a transformer, the transformer will default to
1179     * putting a {@code Document} node there, and then it will not accept a
1180     * fragment.
1181     *<p>
1182     * If you need to handle fragments, this method illustrates how to pre-load
1183     * the {@code DOMResult} with an empty {@code DocumentFragment}. Note that
1184     * if you use some XML processing package that supplies its own classes
1185     * implementing DOM nodes, you may need to use a {@code DocumentFragment}
1186     * instance obtained from that package.
1187     */
1188    public static void allowFragment(DOMResult r) throws SQLException
1189    {
1190        try
1191        {
1192            r.setNode(DocumentBuilderFactory.newInstance()
1193                .newDocumentBuilder().newDocument()
1194                    .createDocumentFragment());
1195        }
1196        catch ( ParserConfigurationException pce )
1197        {
1198            throw new SQLException("Failed initializing DOMResult", pce);
1199        }
1200    }
1201
1202    private static void shovelBytes(InputStream is, OutputStream os)
1203    throws IOException
1204    {
1205        byte[] b = new byte[8192];
1206        int got;
1207        while ( -1 != (got = is.read(b)) )
1208            os.write(b, 0, got);
1209        is.close();
1210        os.close();
1211    }
1212
1213    private static void shovelChars(Reader r, Writer w)
1214    throws IOException
1215    {
1216        char[] b = new char[8192];
1217        int got;
1218        while ( -1 != (got = r.read(b)) )
1219            w.write(b, 0, got);
1220        r.close();
1221        w.close();
1222    }
1223
1224    /**
1225     * Test the MappedUDT (in one direction anyway).
1226     *<p>
1227     * Creates a {@code PassXML} object, the Java class that maps the
1228     * {@code javatest.onexml} composite type, which has one member, of XML
1229     * type. Stores a {@code SQLXML} value in that field of the {@code PassXML}
1230     * object, and passes that to an SQL query that expects and returns
1231     * {@code javatest.onexml}. Retrieves the XML from the value field of the
1232     * {@code PassXML} object created to map the result of the query.
1233     * @return The original XML value, if all goes well.
1234     */
1235    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml")
1236    public static SQLXML xmlFromComposite() throws SQLException
1237    {
1238        Connection c = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
1239        PreparedStatement ps =
1240            c.prepareStatement("SELECT CAST(? AS javatest.onexml)");
1241        SQLXML x = c.createSQLXML();
1242        x.setString("<a/>");
1243        PassXML obj = new PassXML();
1244        obj.m_value = x;
1245        obj.m_typeName = "javatest.onexml";
1246        ps.setObject(1, obj);
1247        ResultSet r = ps.executeQuery();
1248        r.next();
1249        obj = (PassXML)r.getObject(1);
1250        ps.close();
1251        return obj.m_value;
1252    }
1253
1254    /*
1255     * Required to serve as a MappedUDT:
1256     */
1257    /**
1258     * No-arg constructor required of objects that will implement
1259     * {@link SQLData}.
1260     */
1261    public PassXML() { }
1262
1263    private String m_typeName;
1264    private SQLXML m_value;
1265
1266    @Override
1267    public String getSQLTypeName() { return m_typeName; }
1268
1269    @Override
1270    public void readSQL(SQLInput stream, String typeName) throws SQLException
1271    {
1272        m_typeName = typeName;
1273        m_value = (SQLXML) stream.readObject();
1274    }
1275
1276    @Override
1277    public void writeSQL(SQLOutput stream) throws SQLException
1278    {
1279        stream.writeSQLXML(m_value);
1280    }
1281
1282    /**
1283     * Class that will proxy methods to another {@code SQLXML} class.
1284     *<p>
1285     * Used for testing the PL/Java can accept input for PostgreSQL from an
1286     * {@code SQLXML} object not of its own implementation (for example, one
1287     * obtained from a different JDBC driver from some other database).
1288     *<p>
1289     * Only the {@code getSource} method is specially treated, to allow
1290     * exercising the various flavors of source.
1291     */
1292    public static class SQLXMLProxy implements SQLXML
1293    {
1294        private SQLXML m_sx;
1295        private int m_how;
1296
1297        public SQLXMLProxy(SQLXML sx, int how)
1298        {
1299            if ( null == sx )
1300                throw new NullPointerException("Null SQLXMLProxy target");
1301            if ( 1 > how  ||  how > 7  ||  how == 3 )
1302                throw new IllegalArgumentException(
1303                    "\"how\" must be 1, 2, 4, 5, 6, or 7");
1304            m_sx = sx;
1305            m_how = how;
1306        }
1307
1308        @Override
1309        public void free() throws SQLException { m_sx.free(); }
1310
1311        @Override
1312        public InputStream getBinaryStream() throws SQLException
1313        {
1314            return m_sx.getBinaryStream();
1315        }
1316
1317        @Override
1318        public OutputStream setBinaryStream() throws SQLException
1319        {
1320            return m_sx.setBinaryStream();
1321        }
1322
1323        @Override
1324        public Reader getCharacterStream() throws SQLException
1325        {
1326            return m_sx.getCharacterStream();
1327        }
1328
1329        @Override
1330        public Writer setCharacterStream() throws SQLException
1331        {
1332            return m_sx.setCharacterStream();
1333        }
1334
1335        @Override
1336        public String getString() throws SQLException
1337        {
1338            return m_sx.getString();
1339        }
1340
1341        @Override
1342        public void setString(String value) throws SQLException
1343        {
1344            m_sx.setString(value);
1345        }
1346
1347        @Override
1348        @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") // all the fun's when sourceClass is null
1349        public <T extends Source> T getSource(Class<T> sourceClass)
1350        throws SQLException
1351        {
1352            if ( null == sourceClass )
1353            {
1354                switch ( m_how )
1355                {
1356                case 1:
1357                    return (T)new StreamSource(m_sx.getBinaryStream());
1358                case 2:
1359                    return (T)new StreamSource(m_sx.getCharacterStream());
1360                case 4:
1361                    sourceClass = (Class<T>)StreamSource.class;
1362                    break;
1363                case 5:
1364                    sourceClass = (Class<T>)SAXSource.class;
1365                    break;
1366                case 6:
1367                    sourceClass = (Class<T>)StAXSource.class;
1368                    break;
1369                case 7:
1370                    sourceClass = (Class<T>)DOMSource.class;
1371                    break;
1372                }
1373            }
1374            return m_sx.getSource(sourceClass);
1375        }
1376
1377        @Override
1378        public <T extends Result> T setResult(Class<T> resultClass)
1379        throws SQLException
1380        {
1381            return m_sx.setResult(resultClass);
1382        }
1383    }
1384
1385    /**
1386     * Class that will mock an {@code SQLXML} instance, returning only binary or
1387     * character stream data from a byte array or string supplied at
1388     * construction.
1389     */
1390    public static class SQLXMLMock implements SQLXML
1391    {
1392        private String m_chars;
1393        private byte[] m_bytes;
1394
1395        public SQLXMLMock(String content)
1396        {
1397            if ( null == content )
1398                throw new NullPointerException("Null SQLXMLMock content");
1399            m_chars = content;
1400        }
1401
1402        public SQLXMLMock(byte[] content)
1403        {
1404            if ( null == content )
1405                throw new NullPointerException("Null SQLXMLMock content");
1406            m_bytes = content;
1407        }
1408
1409        @Override
1410        public void free() throws SQLException { }
1411
1412        @Override
1413        public InputStream getBinaryStream() throws SQLException
1414        {
1415            if ( null != m_bytes )
1416                return new ByteArrayInputStream(m_bytes);
1417            throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
1418                "SQLXMLMock.getBinaryStream");
1419        }
1420
1421        @Override
1422        public OutputStream setBinaryStream() throws SQLException
1423        {
1424            throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
1425                "SQLXMLMock.setBinaryStream");
1426        }
1427
1428        @Override
1429        public Reader getCharacterStream() throws SQLException
1430        {
1431            if ( null != m_chars )
1432                return new StringReader(m_chars);
1433            throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
1434                "SQLXMLMock.getCharacterStream");
1435        }
1436
1437        @Override
1438        public Writer setCharacterStream() throws SQLException
1439        {
1440            throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
1441                "SQLXMLMock.setCharacterStream");
1442        }
1443
1444        @Override
1445        public String getString() throws SQLException
1446        {
1447            if ( null != m_chars )
1448                return m_chars;
1449            throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
1450                "SQLXMLMock.getString");
1451        }
1452
1453        @Override
1454        public void setString(String value) throws SQLException
1455        {
1456            throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
1457                "SQLXMLMock.setString");
1458        }
1459
1460        @Override
1461        @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") // sourceClass==StreamSource is verified
1462        public <T extends Source> T getSource(Class<T> sourceClass)
1463        throws SQLException
1464        {
1465            if ( null != sourceClass && StreamSource.class != sourceClass )
1466                throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
1467                    "SQLXMLMock.getSource(" + sourceClass.getName() + ")");
1468            if ( null != m_chars )
1469                return (T) new StreamSource(new StringReader(m_chars));
1470            return (T) new StreamSource(new ByteArrayInputStream(m_bytes));
1471        }
1472
1473        @Override
1474        public <T extends Result> T setResult(Class<T> resultClass)
1475        throws SQLException
1476        {
1477            throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
1478                "SQLXMLMock.setResult");
1479        }
1480    }
1481}
